title: Hieracium albertinum
text:
Hieracium albertinum, known as western hawkweed or houndstongue hawkweed, is a <a href="species">species</a> of the <a href="genus">genus</a> "<a href="Hieracium">Hieracium</a>" that is very similar to "<a href="Hieracium%20albiflorum">Hieracium albiflorum</a>" with <a href="white">white</a> <a href="flower">flower</a>s but differs in that the <a href="Head%20%28botany%29">flower heads</a> are clustered and the leaves, stems and bracts are covered in a thick layer of <a href="Trichome">hairs</a>. Standing to tall, it can be found blooming from June through August in forest clearings.
"<a href="Hieracium%20scouleri">Hieracium scouleri</a>" or Scouler's woollyweed, which has also been accepted as a synonym for "Hieracium albertinum", has a different distribution range and yellow flowers.
There is some concern for "Hieracium albertinum" (and other native species) because while they are members of the genus "Hieracium" whose <a href="Introduced%20species">introduced</a> <a href="species">species</a> are often aggressively <a href="Invasive%20species">invasive</a> or weedy, reproducing <a href="Vegetative%20reproduction">vegetatively</a> from aboveground runners called <a href="stolons">stolons</a> or from wandering underground stems called <a href="rhizome">rhizome</a>s, the less aggressive <a href="Indigenous%20%28ecology%29">native</a> hawkweeds reproduce only by reseeding. 
While not listed as <a href="Endangered%20species">endangered</a>, "H. albertinum" is somewhat threatened while its environment is overrun by the aggressive non-native family as well as being listed as a <a href="noxious%20weed">noxious weed</a> due to its membership in the same genus.
Distribution.
"Hieracium albertinum" is native to <a href="North%20America">North America</a> and found east of the <a href="Cascade%20Range">Cascades</a> in the states of <a href="Idaho">Idaho</a>, <a href="Montana">Montana</a>, <a href="Oregon">Oregon</a>, <a href="Washington%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Washington</a> and <a href="Wyoming">Wyoming</a>.
